definitions.definition: a strong shoe that covers the foot and ankle and often the lower part of the leg

examples.text: a pair of heavy walking boots
a pair of black leather boots

definitions.definition: the space at the back of a car that you put bags, cases, etc. in

examples.text: I'll put the luggage in the boot.
What have you got in the boot?
He gave the ball a tremendous boot.

definitions.definition: a device that is attached to the wheel of a car that has been parked illegally, so that it cannot be driven away
to be told that you must leave your job or that a relationship you are having with somebody is over

examples.text: He should have been given the boot years ago.

definitions.definition: to be/become too proud of yourself; to behave as if you are more important than you really are
used to say that a situation has changed so that somebody now has power or authority over the person who used to have power or authority over them
used to invite somebody to take as much as they like of something such as food, drink, etc.; help yourself
to do somebody’s job in an acceptable way when they are not there
to show too much respect for somebody in authority because you want to please them
to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation

examples.text: I wonder if the press will put the boot in?

definitions.definition: to be very frightened or nervous
used to add a comment to something that you have said

examples.text: He was a vegetarian, and a fussy one to boot.

definitions.definition: very strong and able to deal successfully with difficult conditions or situations

examples.text: She’s almost 90 but she’s still as tough as old boots.

wordOrigin: noun Middle English: from Old Norse bóti or its source, Old French bote, of unknown ultimate origin. to boot. Old English bōt ‘advantage, remedy’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch boete and German Busse ‘penance, fine’, also to better and best.
